facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 78 of 1954 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 78 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal from Bombay High Court judgment and decree dated April 17, 1950 in Appeal No. 642 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 17, 1950, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 642 of 1949,

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and decree dated July 30, 1949 of Court of Civil Judge, Senior Division, Ahmedabad in Suit No. 10 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and decree dated July 30, 1949, of the Court of Civil Judge, Senior Division, Ahmedabad in Suit No. 10 of 1946.

facts.text: Appellants are partners of M S. Navinchandra Co.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are the partners of M S. Navinchandra Co. This partnership had placed an order with the respondent

facts.text: Plaintiffs placed order for 251 bales of printed chints on or about July 4, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: This partnership had placed an order with the respondent for 251 bales of printed chints on or about July 4, 1942,

facts.text: Order for 251 bales accepted by respondent by letters dated July 11 and July 20, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: and the said order had been accepted by the respondent by its letters dated July 1 1 and July 20, 1942.

facts.text: Delivery period for 251 bales fixed for September and October 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The delivery period for the said goods was fixed for the months of September and October, 1942.

facts.text: Another order for 31 bales placed July 24, 1942, accepted July 25, 1942, delivery October 1942.

anchor.surface_text: Another order was placed by the appellants with the respondent for 31 bales of printed chints on July 24, 1942, and this order was accepted by the respondent on July 25, 1942.

facts.text: Workers in respondent mills went on strike on August 9, 1942 in sympathy with Quit-India movement.

anchor.surface_text: On August 9, 1942, the workers in the respondent mills went on strike in sympathy with the Quit-India, movement which had then companymenced.

facts.text: Respondent wrote to appellants on August 15, 1942 extending delivery time automatically for period mills stopped and until normal state of affairs recurred.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence, the respondent wrote to the appellants firm on August 15, 1942, and stated that, in view of the strike and the political situation,

facts.text: Strike ended and mills resumed working on November 22, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The strike came to an end and the mills resumed working on November 22, 1942.

facts.text: On December 5, 1942, Keshavlal and Ratilal approached Jasubhai for delivery, told contracts void.

anchor.surface_text: On December 5, 1942, Jasubhai, who was then in charge of the management of the mills was approached by the appellants, Keshavlal and Ratilal,

facts.text: Jasubhai wrote to appellants on December 6, 1942 that contracts null and void.

anchor.surface_text: On December 6, 1942, the said Jasubhai wrote to the appellants informing them that their companytracts were number binding on the mills as they were null and void.

facts.text: Managing agency of mills transferred from Chinubhai Lalbhai to Jasubhai and Babubhai on September 18, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned at this stage that, when the companytracts were made between the appellants and the respondent, Chinubhai Lalbhai was in charge of the managing agency of the mills.

facts.text: Appellants wrote to respondent on December 17, 1942 demanding delivery.

anchor.surface_text: On December 17, 1942, the appellants wrote to the respondent that, as the respondent had extended the time of delivery of all goods by its letter dated August 15, 1942,

facts.text: Respondent replied on December 20, 1942 repeating contentions.

anchor.surface_text: In reply, the respondent repeated its earlier companytentions by its letter dated December 20, 1942.

facts.text: Appellants demanded delivery in January and February 1943.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then formally demanded the delivery of goods in January and again in February 1943,

facts.text: Suit filed on January 9, 1946 claiming Rs. 1,52,334-8-9 damages.

anchor.surface_text: and, since the demand was number companyplied with, the appellants filed the present suit on January 9, 1946, claiming damages to the extent of Rs. 1,52,334-8-9

facts.text: Trial court decreed appellants' claim on July 30, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs claim had been decreed by the trial companyrt but on appeal it has been dismissed.

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed suit on April 17, 1950 holding no agreement on extension and barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: against the decree passed by the High Court of Bombay dismissing their suit to recover from the defendant Rs. 1,52,334-8-9 as damages for breach of companytract

holdings.reasoning_summary: Oral testimony reliable based on consistency, probabilities (rising prices), absence of denial in respondent's letters; conduct shows no demand during strike, first demand post-reopening.

holdings.text: Having regard to the probabilities in this case, and to the conduct of the parties at the relevant time, we think the appellants are entitled to urge that their oral evidence about the acceptance of the respondents proposal for the extension of time should be believed and the finding of the learned trial judge on this question should be confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the probabilities in this case, and to the conduct of the parties at the relevant time, we think the appellants are entitled to urge that their oral evidence about the acceptance of the respondents proposal for the extension of time should be believed and the finding of the learned trial judge on this question should be confirmed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Confirms trial court finding against High Court reversal; evidence and conduct prove acceptance.

holdings.text: The true legal position in regard to the extension of time for the performance of a contract is quite clear under s. 63 of the Indian Contract Act. Every promisee may extend time for the performance of the contract. ... both the buyer and the seller must agree to extend time for the delivery of goods. ... It may be proved by oral evidence. In some cases it may be proved by evidence of conduct.

anchor.surface_text: under s. 63 of the Indian Contract Act. Every promise, as the section provides, may extend time for the performance of the contract. The question as to how extension of time may be agreed upon by the parties

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unilateral extension invalid; requires bilateral assent, provable orally, by conduct, or forbearance; fact-specific.

holdings.text: We must, therefore, hold that the learned Judges of the High Court were right in coming to the conclusion that the conditions mentioned by the respondent in its letter asking for extension of time were so vague and uncertain that it is not possible to ascertain definitely the period for which the time for the performance of the contract was really intended to be extended. In such a case, the agreement for extension must be held to be vague and uncertain and as such void under s. 29 of the Indian Contract Act.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore hold that the learned Judges of the High Court were right in coming to the conclusion that the conditions

holdings.reasoning_summary: Letter's second condition ('till normal state of affairs recurs') indefinable (political, workforce, materials unspecified); not severable (unlike Nicolene); analogous to Scammell; plaint shows partial acceptance only.

holdings.text: That is why it was held that the appellants suit was barred by time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No valid extension revives original delivery period (Sept-Oct 1942); suit filed Jan 1946 exceeds limitation.

holdings.text: It cannot be said that it was not open to the High Court to allow such a plea to be raised even for the first time in appeal. After all, the plea raised is a plea of law based solely upon the construction of the letter which is the basis of the case for the extension of time for the performance of the contract and so it was competent to the appeal court to allow such a plea to be raised under O. 41, r. 2, of the Code of Civil Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pure question of law on document construction; no new facts needed.

holdings.text: If, on a fair construction, the condition mentioned in the document is held to be vague or uncertain, no evidence can be admitted to remove the said vagueness or uncertainty. The provisions of s. 93 of the Indian Evidence Act are clear on this point. It is the language of the document alone that will decide the question.

anchor.surface_text: In support of this argument reliance was placed on the decision in Nicolene Ld. v. Simmonds 1 . In that case, a companytract for the sale of a quantity of reinforcing steel bars was expressed as subject to the usual companyditions of acceptance . The seller repudiated the companytract whereupon the buyers claimed and were awarded by the trial judge damages for the breach of companytract. On appeal, the seller companytended that the companytract was number companycluded there being numberconsensus ad item in regard to the companyditions of acceptance. It was held that, there being numberusual companyditions of acceptance , the companydition was meaningless and should be ignored, and that the 1 1953 1 Q. B. 543, 552.

precedents.cited_proposition: A vague and uncertain condition that is meaningless can be severed and ignored without impairing the contract
precedents.cited_holding: that clause was so vague and uncertain as to be incapable of any precise meaning. It is clearly severable from the rest of the companytract. It can be rejected without impairing the sense or reasonableness of the companytract as a whole, and it should be so rejected. The companytract should be held good and the clause ignored

precedents.citation: Scammel G. And Nephew, Ld. v. Ouston H. C. And J. 0. 1 [1941] A.C. 251

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, we may usefully refer to the decision of the House of Lords in Scammel G. And Nephew, Ld. v. Ouston H. C. And J. 0. 1 . In this case, the respondent had agreed to purchase from the appellant a new motor-van but stipulated that this order was given on the understanding that the balance of purchase price can be had on the hire-purchase terms over a. period of two years. The House of Lords held that the clause as to hire-purchase terms was so vague that numberprecise meaning could be attributed to it and consequently there was numberenforceable companytract between the parties.

precedents.cited_proposition: Agreement with vague and uncertain terms is void and unenforceable as there is no consensus
